label: [Blockly] Visual Coding: Drawing Parallels
info:
### Aim

This is the flow for the basis of the article [Visual Coding: Drawing Parallels](https://blog.openmindmap.org/blog/visual-code-drawing-parallels).

### Requirements

- [Blockly](https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-blockly) for Node-RED.
- [Flow2UML](https://flows.nodered.org/node/@gregoriusrippenstein/node-red-contrib-flow2uml) for generating Mermaid UML flowcharts from flows in Node-RED.

### TL;DR

We as programmers should choose representations of code that is understandable by *our audience* and not by us. We are, after all, not *coders* but *programmers* and as such, we also program our audience with our words. Sometimes knowing who the audience is, can be difficult however it should not be an excuse for not making an effort.

### Description

There are many *visual* representations of programs, there are even various possible interpretations of the *same* [visual representation](https://blog.openmindmap.org/blog/pipes-wires-nodes).   In this article I compare [Blockly](https://developers.google.com/blockly/) with Node-RED code. Blockly is a form of programming that reminds me of [LEGO® MINDSTORMS®](https://www.lego.com/en-us/themes/mindstorms) and the early versions which used a similar visual paradigm to allow children to program their robots.

I never found that visual representation to be either intuitive nor easy to understand but then again, I cannot play the piano either! Everyone is different and everyone has a different analogy when it comes to programming algorithms. Therefore we as programmers should be careful in the selection of our representations.

name: function 23
